overview.summary: An interactive spelling bee game inspired by The New York Times Spelling Bee, built with React and Bun as part of the Advanced Web Programming Techniques course at Vanier College.
overview.problem: Building interactive front-end applications requires a solid understanding of state management, component structure, and user-driven logic.
overview.solution: A small but complete game application that uses React state and hooks to manage gameplay, user input, and dynamic UI updates.

responsibilities: Designed and implemented the game logic using React state and hooks
Built reusable and readable React components
Handled user input, word validation, and game state updates
Configured and ran the project locally using Bun for development

architecture.approach: Component-based React application with local state management, focused on clarity and separation of concerns.
architecture.data_flow: Game state is managed using React state and hooks, with data flowing down through components and user actions triggering updates.
architecture.deployment: Currently runs locally using Bun's development server; deployment planned for a later stage.

key_features: Interactive spelling bee gameplay inspired by The New York Times
Dynamic UI updates based on user input
State-driven game logic using React hooks
Clean component structure for maintainability and readability
challenges_and_learnings: Managing game state cleanly across multiple components
Using React hooks effectively for interactive logic
Structuring components to avoid unnecessary re-renders
Debugging and testing user-driven edge cases
future_improvements: Deploy the application for public access
Add scoring rules and difficulty levels
